High-quality child-care programs are linked to greater achievement and success in a child’s life. They are also necessary for many Virginia families in which parents or guardians work during the day.

The Department of Social Services’ Child Care Subsidy Program assists Virginians in paying for child-care costs. If you are eligible and are approved for services, the Subsidy Program can pay a portion of your child-care costs directly to the child-care provider.

To be eligible, children must be either:

Under age 13 and not eligible to attend public school during the part of the day when public education is available

Under age 18 with special needs

Virginians can easily check their eligibility or apply online using the CommonHelp application. You can also apply in-person at a local DSS office. To learn more about the Child Care Subsidy Program, visit the DSS website.

Virginia Medicaid is always accepting applications.

Jada shared her mug cake with Flat Mrs. South.

Good afternoon King and Queen Community, this is Dr. Carter calling with an update. I would first like to give a shout out to the families that participated on our Facebook Spirit Week. It was nice to see everyone’s virtual spirit. Also, a congratulations to Ms. Doan and Ms. Walsh for their 4th grade class winning the March Madness with their book, The BFG.

Another shout out goes to our school nutrition team. They will start back up with meals tomorrow, Monday, April 13th. We will continue to have meals distributed on Mondays and Thursdays from 11:00 A.M. till 12:00 P.M. and continue through June 11th. We will be using the same 5 locations: Upper King and Queen Firehouse, Lawson Marriott Elementary, Central High School, King and Queen Elementary, and the Lower King and Queen Firehouse.

There will be another update mid-week regarding instruction, communication, personal student belongings, and grading.

Happy Easter to all and be safe.

Thank you.

From Mrs. Curle

To the CHS Class of 2020

You are the class who lost
your last months as the top dogs
your right to be the kings and queens of the school
your need to fix the mistakes
your time to dance and celebrate
your moment to shine
your belief in what is fair
your right to say goodbye
your rite of passage.

It isn’t fair.
It isn’t right.
It stole a moment in time that will never be given back.
But…

You are the class who will gain perspective
will understand that nothing is promised
will fix your mistakes soon after you make them
will celebrate with the ones who matter
will find other ways to shine
will not need life to be fair to do a job well done
will love your friends and family more deeply
will appreciate those who taught you
will know what it means to “grow up”
will be the hope for the future
Because
You matter.
You are important.
You are our legacy.

King and Queen County Public Schools wants our school community to know a threat was averted today without incident. A student who had recently transferred to the high school was reported by other students to be bragging about having a gun. Based on those reports, the School Resource Officer searched the student, and took possession of a handgun. The student was arrested and taken into custody.

We are grateful for the wisdom and prompt action of our students, and the courage and professionalism of our SRO. Together, they kept our student body and staff safe, and neutralized the threat without undue disruption.

Any further statements will come from law enforcement. The school district cannot comment further because of student privacy laws.

Ideas 💡 for what to ask your child when they get home from school. Our hope is that King and Queen families feel engaged in their child’s education, even while leading busy lives!

1. What was the best thing about your day at school?
2. What was the hardest thing about your day at school?
3. What was the funniest thing about your day at school?
4. What was the kindest thing somebody did today at school?
5. Did something happen at school today that made you feel proud? Tell me about it!

October is Disability History and Awareness Month

One of every five Americans is a person with a disability. A person may be born with a disability, may acquire a disability through an accident or illness, or may acquire a disability simply as a part of growing older. Despite the fact that disability is a natural part of life, people with disabilities have not always had access to equal opportunities. Not until 1975, with the passage of the Federal Education for All Handicapped Children Act (now known as the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act), did school-aged children with disabilities have a right to a free appropriate public education.

The Virginia Department of Education has worked to share many initiatives which support students with disabilities.

October Is VSBA Bullying Prevention Month

School board members, superintendents, teachers and parents can play a critical role in creating a climate where bullying is not tolerated. It has been proven when adults and children stand together, bullying ends. This is why the Virginia School Boards Association (VSBA) has declared October to be VSBA Bullying Prevention Month.

Childhood bullying is a significant problem nationwide. It can cause school absenteeism, mental and physical stress, poor school performance, poor self-esteem, and, in some cases, school violence. Over twenty percent of all school-aged children are bullied each year - upwards of thirteen million students.

King and Queen County is committed to preventing bullying. If you or someone you know is experiencing bullying, please contact one of our school administrators.

In long, when I was in high school I was headed for either jail or a coffin. Divorced parents, physically and emotionally abusive mother and just all around bad youthful behavior. The father of a friend of mine was the Army JROTC instructor at my high school and he convinced me to join the JROTC program. My selfish goal is to be that person who makes that kind of difference in a student's life because I know how valuable it can be.

Did you know that ALL schools in King and Queen had major improvements in the area of Chronic Absenteeism?

Thank you parents and students for knowing that attendance matters.

Chronic absenteeism is missing 10% of the school days, which is about 18 absences/year or about 2 absences/month. Being on time and staying all day is important too 🙂 A few quick tips:

1. When you are sick, please take care of yourself and stay home from school to avoid the spread of germs.

2. Visit the doctor if your illness is going to keep you out of school more than two days. They can help with a speedier recovery sometimes.

3. Other emergencies come up too. We understand. Always communicate with the school when your child has been absent. A doctor’s note or parent note works great!

4. Try to schedule appointments outside school hours whenever possible.

Attendance Works has more great information and tips!

https://www.attendanceworks.org/resources/handouts-for-families/

What’s Your Why Wednesday
Teacher Feature: Dr. Swanson

When my son was younger, I volunteered at his elementary school because I wanted to get involved. When I asked questions about various things that pertained to programs I was interested in, I got interesting looks and responses from educators in his setting. I couldn’t figure out why. Once I was told he had made a “bad” choice for a friend when he gravitated to the only other young boy who looked like him in the class. These experiences peeked my curiosity about how African American males were viewed and treated in educational settings. I decided I wanted to become a part of the support system for this student group to ensure they got a fair shot at an education that would allow them to dream and become!!!
